articles.title: Is htmx Just Another JavaScript Framework?
articles.description: Despite being four years old, htmx has seen a surge in popularity recently, parly due to fatigue with 'big frameworks' and also because its simple HTML-based approach to adding functionality to a page appeals to an increasingly diverse group. But is it just another framework itself? Yes. And no.
articles.author: Alexander Petros

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†HTMX for React Developers in 10 Minutes
articles.description: You're not interested in discussions about semantics.. you just want to get something done with htmx? Here, Jack takes ten minutes to show off the essentials.
articles.author: Jack Herrington

articles.title: 33 JavaScript Concepts Every Developer Should Know
articles.description: A curated collection of links to tutorials on 33 different areas worth understanding well, including: types, closures, equality, scope, and different engines. We linked this two years ago, but it remains frequently updated.
articles.author: Leonardo Maldonado

articles.title: Introducing fsx: A Modern Filesystem API for JavaScript
articles.description: Filesystem APIs in JavaScript runtimes haven‚Äôt been great for a long time. This is one prominent JavaScript expert‚Äôs attempt to make a better one.
articles.author: Nicholas C. Zakas

articles.title: The Website vs. Web App Dichotomy Doesn't Exist
articles.description: An interesting think piece that will help you flesh out your own opinions on the matter: ‚ÄúIf there‚Äôs one takeaway from all this, it‚Äôs that the web is a flexible medium where any number of technologies can be combined in all sorts of interesting ways.‚Äù
articles.author: Jake Lazaroff

articles.title: Rust-Based JavaScript Linters: Fast, But No Typed Linting Right Now
articles.description: An explanation of why the speed gains from Rust-powered linters aren‚Äôt comparable to the full feature set of typescript-eslint.
articles.author: Josh Goldberg

articles.title: The State of Benchmarking in Node.js
articles.description: While Node has always been fast (thanks largely to its V8 underpinnings), there‚Äôs a renewed focus on performance in the face of benchmarks and claims from alternatives like Deno and Bun. Lars looks at the ecosystem of benchmarking options in the space.
articles.author: Lars Kappert

articles.title: A CSS Media Query for Scripting Support
articles.description: A new media query (e.g. @media (scripting: none)) was just added to Chrome (and Edge) to let you to define styles upon whether scripting languages are available. It's supported in all major browsers now ‚Äì a rare case of Chromium playing catch-up!
articles.author: Stephanie Stimac

articles.title: ‚ñ∂¬†¬†What is Remix Exactly?
articles.description: As in Remix, the full-stack web framework.
articles.author: Alem Tuzlak

articles.title: zip.js: Library to Zip and Unzip Files
articles.description: Sounds simple, and it is, but it supports a couple of different formats and can generate password protected ZIPs. There are a few demos, but the simplest one sold me on its own. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Gildas Lormeau

articles.title: Element Plus: Vue 3 Component Library
articles.description: Out of the box you get a large variety of clean components with a minimal vibe. You can see them in action here.
articles.author: Element Plus Team

articles.title: RE2JS: Linear Time Matching for Regular Expressions
articles.description: RE2 is a regex engine built by Google designed to operate in time proportional to the size of the input, in order to avoid so-called ‚ÄòReDoS‚Äô problems backtracking can cause. There are bindings for Node.js, but this version works in the browser.
articles.author: Oleksii Vasyliev

articles.title: Penrose: Beautiful Math Diagrams by Writing Plain Text
articles.description: It might sound a little like Mermaid (indeed, their homepages are strikingly similar) but its scope feels somewhat more math-focused ‚Äì there are many examples.
articles.author: Penrose Contributors

articles.title: DOMPurify 3.0.8: A Fast, Tolerant XSS Sanitizer for HTML
articles.description: Supports all modern browsers and is heavily tested. There‚Äôs a live demo here.
articles.author: Cure53

articles.title: remoteStorage: Cross Browser/Device Persistence
articles.description: Combines the localStorage API with a remote server to persist data across browsers and devices ‚Äì so basically, imagine localStorage but remote. Here‚Äôs the server part.
articles.author: Frigade

articles.description: CodePen shares its top 100 'pens' of 2023. Lots of fantastic bits and pieces to look through and learn from here.
Bored? The Deno team is running a little hackathon over the next week.
jsfree.org is a new effort to catalog web services that can work without JavaScript.
üåº Enjoy the drawing.garden.
Docusaurus 3.1 ‚Äì Popular site generator/framework.
Rspack 0.5 ‚Äì Fast Rust-based web bundler.
MikroORM 6 ‚Äì TypeScript ORM for Node.js.
Node.js v20.11.0 (LTS), Bun 1.0.22, npm 10.3 and Astro 4.1.

articles.title: How Google 'Perfected' the Web
articles.description: An extensive look at how Google‚Äôs dominance has ultimately shaped the web, resulting in a web that's filled with content designed for Google, not necessarily humans. (Not only is it an interesting article, but also a striking piece of modern editorial Web design.)
articles.author: Mia Sato (The Verge)

articles.title: The Top Pens of 2023 on CodePen
articles.description: An always enjoyable round-up of the year in CodePen demos. There‚Äôs bound to be something here you find interesting or novel ‚Äî and there‚Äôs always takeaways to be had in terms of how things have been approached too. 100 demos in total, including lovely WebGL flowers, a CSS 3D maze, and a glowing shadow effect.
articles.author: CodePen

articles.title: üîÆ Frontend Predictions for 2024
articles.description: Because who doesn‚Äôt like some soothsaying on where things are heading? Some nuanced thoughts on ‚Äòowning‚Äô the frontend stack, the rise of AI, UI frameworks and more.
articles.author: Jamie Birch

articles.title: The Popular Vote of Interop 2024
articles.description: We will soon be learning what the focus for Interop will be in 2024, but ahead of that Chris attempts to tally up what proposals might be front and centre in terms of attention (from a total of 103!) ‚Äî including scroll-driven animations, JPEG XL, and more.
articles.author: Chris Coyier

articles.title: The Website vs. Web App Dichotomy Doesn't Exist
articles.description: ‚Äúthe web is a flexible medium where any number of technologies can be combined in all sorts of interesting ways...‚Äù
articles.author: Jake Lazaroff

articles.title: New CSS Viewport Units Don't Solve the Classic Scrollbar¬†Problem
articles.description: On the problem with 100vw, how browsers handle scrollbars, and what future solutions we may have to solve the issue.
articles.author: ≈†ime Vidas

articles.title: The World's Smallest PNG
articles.description: It takes 67 bytes to make one pixel. Evan dives into how it works.
articles.author: Evan Hahn

articles.title: My Web Development Wishlist 2024
articles.description: Some broad but well intentioned wishes.
articles.author: Jens Oliver Meiert

articles.title: Using Cutting Edge CSS Features to Build a Progress Indicator
articles.description: Brings together things like scroll linked animations, CSS trig functions, and color-mix properties to create a progress indicator linked to the current scroll position of the page, without any JS.
articles.author: Andrico Karoulla

articles.title: CSS Media Query for Scripting Support
articles.description: A new ‚Äòscripting‚Äô media query (e.g. @media (scripting: none)), recently added to Chrome, looks to be a powerful addition to the progressive enhancement toolbox ‚Äî it allows you to test whether scripting languages are available and tailor page content and styles based upon this.
articles.author: Stephanie Stimac

articles.title: 'My CSS Resets'
articles.description: How folks approach a CSS reset always seems to be of interest, so here‚Äôs Keith‚Äôs take on it.
articles.author: Keith J. Grant

articles.title: CSS Hooks: A Styling Solution That Brings Advanced CSS Capabilities to Native Inline Styles
articles.description: This solution resembles inline styles and is designed for React, Preact, Solid, and Qwik. And one big plus is no need for a build step, reducing the overall footprint.
articles.author: CSS Hooks

articles.title: remoteStorage: A Cross Browser/Device Persistence Approach
articles.description: Combines the localStorage API with a remote server to persist data across browsers and devices ‚Äì so basically, imagine localStorage but remote. Here‚Äôs how the server part runs.
articles.author: Frigade

articles.title: Makedraft: An AI That Generates Frontend Code Based on Instructions
articles.description: Will generate HTML with Tailwind, JavaScript, or Alpine.js. Also includes the option to highlight code you want changed before adding your text in the prompt.
articles.author: makedraft

articles.title: subiRegex: Generate Regular Expressions with English
articles.description: Type something like ‚ÄúCanadian Postal Code‚Äù or ‚Äú5 numbers followed by an optional letter‚Äù, etc. and this tool will generate the regex for you using AI.
articles.author: Jonathan Kong Boon Lieng

articles.title: Direction-Aware Mickey Mouse
articles.description: Everyone‚Äôs been talking about the copyright status of Steamboat Willie lately, so here‚Äôs Mickey following your pointer and keeping an eye on things‚Ä¶
articles.author: Jon Kantner CodePen

articles.title: Tailplates: A Set of 20+ Responsive Tailwind CSS Templates
articles.description: Includes four categories of templates: agency, blog, ecommerce, and SaaS, with eight different page variations. Not a free project, but the price seems reasonable at $10 for the set.
articles.author: Tailplates
